# Cambridge International AS & A Level

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[735, 214, 905, 256]]<|/det|>  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 276, 324, 293]]<|/det|>
## FURTHER MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 277, 904, 292]]<|/det|>
9231/21  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 301, 368, 317]]<|/det|>
Paper 2 Further Pure Mathematics 2  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[707, 301, 905, 317]]<|/det|>
October/November 2020  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[841, 326, 905, 341]]<|/det|>
2 hours  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 393, 370]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 393, 400]]<|/det|>
You will need: List of formulae (MF19)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 230, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 280, 450]]<|/det|>
Answer all questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 450, 760, 466]]<|/det|>
Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 466, 806, 482]]<|/det|>
Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 482, 562, 497]]<|/det|>
Write your answer to each question in the space provided.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 498, 485, 512]]<|/det|>
Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 513, 361, 527]]<|/det|>
Do not write on any bar codes.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 528, 868, 559]]<|/det|>
If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 560, 480, 575]]<|/det|>
You should use a calculator where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 575, 880, 606]]<|/det|>
You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 606, 860, 637]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 666, 220, 680]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 682, 384, 697]]<|/det|>
The total mark for this paper is 75.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 698, 728, 713]]<|/det|>
The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 77, 99, 96]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 77, 148, 96]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 75, 920, 101]]<|/det|>
By differentiating \(\mathrm{e}^{-x^{2}}\), find the Maclaurin's series for \(\mathrm{e}^{-x^{2}}\) up to and including the term in \(x^{2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 94, 920, 112]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 688, 186, 707]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 682, 920, 725]]<|/det|>
Deduce an approximation to \(\int_{0}^{\frac{1}{5}}\mathrm{e}^{-x^{2}}\mathrm{d}x\), giving your answer as a rational fraction in its lowest terms.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 704, 920, 723]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 96, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 589, 90]]<|/det|>
The variables \(x\) and \(y\) are related by the differential equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[384, 92, 615, 125]]<|/det|>
\[9\frac{\mathrm{d}^{2}y}{\mathrm{d}x^{2}} + 6\frac{\mathrm{d}y}{\mathrm{d}x} + y = 3x^{2} + 30x.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 133, 144, 152]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 133, 500, 152]]<|/det|>
Find the general solution for \(y\) in terms of \(x\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 133, 920, 152]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 780, 186, 798]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 780, 623, 798]]<|/det|>
State an approximate solution for large positive values of \(x\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 781, 920, 800]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 99, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 426, 89]]<|/det|>
Show that the system of equations

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[442, 97, 571, 116]]<|/det|>
\[x - 2y - 4z = 1,\]

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[444, 118, 571, 136]]<|/det|>
\[x - 2y + kz = 1,\]

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[428, 139, 571, 157]]<|/det|>
\[-x + 2y + 2z = 1,\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 164, 581, 183]]<|/det|>
where \(k\) is a constant, does not have a unique solution.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 165, 920, 183]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 444, 141, 462]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 444, 920, 477]]<|/det|>
Given that \(k = -4\), show that the system of equations in part **(a)** is consistent. Interpret this situation geometrically.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 459, 920, 477]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 144, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 73, 920, 107]]<|/det|>
Given instead that \(k = - 2\) , show that the system of equations in part **(a)** is inconsistent. Interpret this situation geometrically.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 85, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 490, 186, 509]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 490, 920, 524]]<|/det|>
For the case where \(k \neq - 2\) and \(k \neq - 4\), show that the system of equations in part **(a)** is inconsistent. Interpret this situation geometrically.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 504, 920, 523]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 303, 143, 320]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 299, 752, 325]]<|/det|>
Use a similar method to find, in terms of \(n\), a lower bound for \(\int_{0}^{1}(1 - x^{3})\mathrm{d}x\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 304, 918, 323]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 72, 96, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 72, 235, 89]]<|/det|>
It is given that

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[391, 100, 606, 121]]<|/det|>
\[x = \sinh^{-1}t,\quad y = \cos^{-1}t,\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 133, 272, 152]]<|/det|>
where \(-1 < t < 1\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 163, 146, 183]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 163, 682, 183]]<|/det|>
By differentiating \(\cos y\) with respect to \(t\), show that \(\frac{\mathrm{d}y}{\mathrm{d}t} = -\frac{1}{\sqrt{1 - t^2}}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 163, 920, 183]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 81, 148, 101]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 75, 532, 109]]<|/det|>
Find \(\frac{\mathrm{d}^{2}y}{\mathrm{dx}^{2}}\) in terms of \(t\), simplifying your answer.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 81, 920, 101]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 75, 96, 94]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 75, 144, 94]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 75, 712, 96]]<|/det|>
Use de Moivre's theorem to show that \(\sin^{4}\theta = \frac{1}{8} (\cos 4\theta - 4\cos 2\theta + 3).\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 75, 920, 94]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 504, 89]]<|/det|>
Find the solution of the differential equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[418, 95, 581, 123]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{\mathrm{d}y}{\mathrm{d}\theta} +y\cot \theta = \sin^3\theta\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 131, 401, 151]]<|/det|>
for which \(y = 0\) when \(\theta = \frac{1}{2}\pi\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 133, 920, 151]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 96, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 314, 89]]<|/det|>
The matrix \(\mathbf{P}\) is given by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[435, 98, 564, 153]]<|/det|>
\[\mathbf{P} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 4 & 2 \\ 0 & -1 & 1 \\ 0 & 0 & 2 \end{pmatrix}.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 165, 144, 183]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 165, 366, 183]]<|/det|>
State the eigenvalues of \(\mathbf{P}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 165, 920, 183]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 350, 143, 368]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 350, 532, 368]]<|/det|>
Use the characteristic equation of \(\mathbf{P}\) to find \(\mathbf{P}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 350, 920, 368]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 72, 781, 92]]<|/det|>
The \(3 \times 3\) matrix \(\mathbf{A}\) has distinct eigenvalues \(b\), \(-1\), 1 with corresponding eigenvectors

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[421, 98, 576, 155]]<|/det|>
\[\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 0 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}, \begin{pmatrix} 4 \\ -1 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}, \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix},\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 166, 220, 184]]<|/det|>
respectively.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 196, 144, 214]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 196, 322, 214]]<|/det|>
Find \(\mathbf{A}\) in terms of \(b\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 197, 918, 215]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 96, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 146, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 806, 92]]<|/det|>
Sketch the graph of \(y = \coth x\) for \(x > 0\) and state the equations of the asymptotes.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 72, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 368, 146, 386]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 367, 811, 386]]<|/det|>
Starting from the definitions of both and cosech in terms of exponentials, prove that

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[408, 396, 591, 416]]<|/det|>
\[\coth^{2}x - \mathrm{cosech}^{2}x = 1.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 396, 920, 415]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 75, 532, 100]]<|/det|>
The curve \(C\) has equation \(y = \ln \coth \left(\frac{1}{2} x\right)\) for \(x > 0\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 106, 144, 127]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 102, 369, 129]]<|/det|>
Show that \(\frac{\mathrm{dy}}{\mathrm{dx}} = -\mathrm{cosech}x.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 107, 920, 127]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 330, 185, 349]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[178, 327, 890, 349]]<|/det|>
It is given that the arc length of \(C\) from \(x = a\) to \(x = 2a\) is \(\ln 4\), where \(a\) is a positive constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 357, 722, 378]]<|/det|>
Show that \(\cosh a = 2\) and find, in logarithmic form, the exact value of \(a\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 358, 920, 376]]<|/det|>
<mark>[7]

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[432, 73, 567, 89]]<|/det|>
# Additional Page  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 102, 920, 136]]<|/det|>
If you use the following lined page to complete the answer(s) to any question(s), the question number(s) must be clearly shown.
